column4: hay guys, I have a strange problem; it seems the only way I can get my Linux distro (ubuntu) to boot is to wait for an initramfs error along the lines of: "job control turned off", upon getting this error I type "modprobe piix", then "exit" and it boots. I have added "piix" to /etc/modules and /etc/initramfs/modules and it *still* wont boot. ideas?
guys, the only way I can get my system to boot from hdd is to type "modprobe piix" each time, could someone help me fix this please
how do you type that before booting?
if you just want to know how to autoload a module, the answer is to put the name of it in /etc/modules
I get an "initramfs" error regarding job control being turned off, I type "modprobe piix" then "exit". The system boots
I have "piix" saved in both /etc/modules and /etc/initramfs-tools/modules, it still refuses to boot though
how do you modprobe before booting?
once booted it's fine - I just need to modprobe piix EVERY time i reboot, rather annoying :-)
maybe you need to modify the initramfs to include the module for some reason. I must admit I'm not into the details, though. Maybe someone else knows better
did you rebuild the initramfs after adding it to /etc/initramfs-tools/modules?
it sounds out of the ordinary
I guess you're unlucky. It's been pretty painless for me for almost two years now
a radical approach would be building your own kernel with that driver built in
I've compiled kernels before, I actually ran the module-assistant looking for piix but I couldn't find it, I don't suppose you know which module would need to be loaded do you?
I don't know what it is to be honest
what is it a driver for?
